answers: Julia the Elder [or Julia daughter of Augustus; do not accept or prompt on “Julia the Younger”]
parts: Name this person had an affair with Sempronius Gracchus. This person’s alleged promiscuity undermined her father’s legislation against adultery, so she was exiled to Pandateria and not allowed to have male visitors.

The Emperor Augustus was much kinder to this third wife of his than to his daughter, Julia. This mother of Tiberius was a key advisor to Augustus despite likely false claims she poisoned him with a fig.
Augustus did not get along super well with this queen and last real ruler of Ptolemaic Egypt, who lost the Battle of Actium along with her lover, Marc Antony.

answers: Julia the Elder [or Julia daughter of Augustus; do not accept or prompt on “Julia the Younger”]
parts: Name this person had an affair with Sempronius Gracchus. This person’s alleged promiscuity undermined her father’s legislation against adultery, so she was exiled to Pandateria and not allowed to have male visitors.

The Emperor Augustus was much kinder to this third wife of his than to his daughter, Julia. This mother of Tiberius was a key advisor to Augustus despite likely false claims she poisoned him with a fig.
Augustus did not get along super well with this queen and last real ruler of Ptolemaic Egypt, who lost the Battle of Actium along with her lover, Marc Antony.

Name this artist of The Ship of Fools who achieved true PKD levels of trippiness by painting stuff like some giant ears with a knife, a Tree Man, and a pig in a nun’s wimple in Hell in The Garden of Earthly Delights.
The outer portion of The Garden of Earthly Delights triptych shows the world as a watery orb and is painted in this black-and-white style, usually intended to imitate sculpture.

This Bosch painting is the right panel of a triptych with The Ship of Fools and Allegory of Gluttony and Lust. It shows an emaciated man lying in bed behind his formerly healthy, rich self while demons creep in at all sides.

answers: Timofey Pavlovich Pnin [accept either underlined part]
parts: Name this professor at Waindell College who tries to reconnect with his son, Victor. In a rare moment of vulnerability, he tearfully cries, “I haf nothing! Nothing!”
Pnin appears in an eponymous novel by this Russian, who created the pedophile Humbert Humbert in Lolita.

Pnin appears in this other Nabokov novel as a professor at Wordsmith University. This novel is presented as a 999-line poem written by a fictional author, with a lengthy forward and commentary also by a fictional author.

answers: The University of Chicago [or UChicago; or U of C]
internalize the externalities [accept word forms for both words; accept phrase variations like the externalities are internalized; prompt on “internalize” alone with “internalize what?”]
parts: Name these things whose absence is also felt in the Coase Theorem. Coase himself later said his theorem didn’t apply in the real world because you can’t describe a world without these.

The Coase Theorem made its first appearance in “The Problem of Social Cost,” an extremely highly cited article in this university’s law review. This university’s namesake school of economics included Milton Friedman.

This situation occurs when external costs borne by a third party are shifted back to the party that created them. Coase argued that low transaction costs make outside intervention to accomplish this unnecessary.
The aforementioned agricultural sect of Buddhism, whose devotees worship at brown cloth altars, originated in this country.
This ethnic group lives in Vietnam, amongst other southeast Asian countries. They have an animistic belief system and look to shamans called txiv neeb (tse neng) to heal various ailments.
Missionaries of this religion created a system for writing Vietnamese in Latin. President Diem was an unpopular practitioner of this religion.

answers: 16S rRNA [prompt on RNA, ribosomal RNA, or rRNA]
parts: Name this third domain, which consists of single-celled organisms that often live in extreme environments.
Unlike the other two domains, archaea use a formylated derivative of this amino acid. This amino acid is encoded by the start codon, and removing its terminal methyl group gives homocysteine.
Carl Woese organized life into 3 domains by sequencing this sub-component of the small ribosomal subunit. Its 3’ end contains the anti-Shine-Dalgarno sequence.

answers: Kerner Commission [also accept National Advisory Commission on Civil Disorders]
parts: Twenty-three civilians were killed in the 12th Street Riot in this city. The riot most likely contributed to the 20th century population decline of this Motor City, which continues to the present day.

This commission was established due to the race riots of 1967 and was named after the Illinois governor who chaired it. It sought to establish the cause of the riots and recommend future actions reducing racial tensions.

This Governor of Maryland lost the support of black voters due to his attempt to prosecute SNCC Chairman H. Rap Brown after 1967 riots in Cambridge. He dubbed opponents “hopeless, hysterical hypochondriacs of history.”

answers: Mary McCarthy (the mentioned novel is The Group)
hell [or obvious synonyms; prompt on the afterlife, the underworld, hereafter, etc]
parts: Name this author, wrote about the disconnected life of Meg Sargent in The Company She Keeps. A novel by this author follows eight female friends at Vassar, including Kay Strong and Helena Davison.

About this author, Mary McCarthy once quipped that “Every word she writes is a lie, including ‘and’ and ‘the.’” Mary Tilford’s lies bring down a girl’s school in this author’s play The Children’s Hour.
In Nora Ephron’s play Imaginary Friends, Hellman and McCarthy recall their feud after meeting in this place. Garcin declares that this place is “other people” in Jean-Paul Sartre’s No Exit.

answers: classification (do not accept or prompt on clustering)
diagonal [prompt on description like “all the non-diagonal elements are zero”]
parts: Name this task in machine learning which predicts labels for new inputs given a set of already-labeled data points.
One interpretation of the Naive Bayes algorithm is that it attempts to fit a distribution to each class where the covariance matrix of the features has this property.

Another interpretation of Naive Bayes is that it assumes that all the features of the data have this relationship. In statistics, two events have this relationship if the outcome of one does not affect the other.
For this ancient Roman holiday which took place in May, the head of the household got up at midnight and walked around the house barefoot throwing black beans to expel ghosts.
On Lemuria, these women would prepare flour cake. These priestesses of the goddess of the hearth were sworn to celibacy and were responsible for keeping a sacred fire from going out.

This two-word Latin phrase was used to celebrate its namesake holiday, on which slaves and masters switched places and gambling was permitted. The emperor yelled this exclamation to the crowd after the opening ceremony.

answers: babies [or equivalents like infants or children]
parts: Name this commodity that Posner and Landes argue has excess demand due to the large number of infertile couples. They argue that restrictions on adoption should be eased to promote efficiency in this commodity.
In “The Ethical Limitations of the Market,” this University of Michigan philosopher argues that economic goods have certain qualities that make them suitable for markets.
Drawing from Mauss and Sahlins, Anderson argues that this type of exchange differs from market exchange because it bonds donor and recipient and allows for delays in reciprocity.

answers: Orange Revolution [or Pomaranchev revolyutsiya; or 2004 Ukrainian Revolution; 2005 Ukrainian Revolution]
parts: Name this Soviet Foreign Minister from 1985 to 1991. This person’s negotiations with U.S. counterpart James Baker after the fall of the Berlin Wall helped lead to the reunification of Germany in the Two Plus Four Agreement.

Shevardnadze is better known as the president of this country from 1995 to 2003, when he was deposed in the peaceful Rose Revolution. This country fought Russia over its border regions of South Ossetia and Abkhazia.

This event took place a year after the Rose Revolution and resulted from voter fraud in an election to succeed Leonid Kuchma. Viktor Yushchenko won the re-run election that occurred as a result of it.

answers: finite support or are zero outside some interval or anything equivalent
parts: Joseph Fourier introduced them while attempting to solve this equation, which states that the time derivative of u is proportional to the Laplacian of u.
The basic idea behind Fourier series is to express arbitrary functions as a sums of these two kinds of basic trigonometric functions, whose squares sum to one.
In signal processing, the Shannon-Nyquist theorem applies to signals whose Fourier transforms have this property, which means that the frequencies of the original function are bounded.

answers: love suicides [accept any manner of self-caused death, such as poisoning oneself, drowning oneself, stabbing oneself, etc]
The Uprooted Pine [or Nebiki no Kadomatsu]
parts: Name this action performed by the lovers Jihei and Koharu at Amijima and Tokubei and Ohatsu at Sonezaki in namesake plays. Romeo and Juliet commit this act at the end of a Shakespeare play.
The Love Suicides at Sonezaki and The Love Suicides at Amijima were written by this bunraku and kabuki dramatist. He also fictionalized historical events in The Battles of Coxinga.
In this other Chikamatsu play, the prostitute Azuma is in love with Yojibei, who cannot marry her due to his wife Okiku. All ends happily when Yohei is able to outbid Hikosuke for Azuma’s freedom.
A flashback to Diane’s time as a barista shows that Mr. Peanutbutter’s second wife was this American actress, who broke up with Mr. Peanutbutter to date Justin Timberlake.

In the first season, Bojack hires this person to ruin Diane’s marriage by enacting a bank robbery. This American actress won multiple Emmys thanks to her roles as Mags Bennett in Justified and as Claudia in The Americans.
In the final segment of Mr. Peanutbutter’s game show, Bojack confuses the similarly-featured Elijah Wood with this actor who plays the titular wizard in the Harry Potter series.

answers: pink [pink tide; pink map; rose-coloured map; mapa cor de rosa]
parts: Give this color that names a “tide” of leftist Latin American leaders who rejected the Washington Consensus in the 1990s. A Portuguese map of this color laid out their claims to the areas of Africa from Angola to Mozambique.
These people lived in part of the land claimed by the Pink Map. These people created the Kingdom of Mutapa, and they built a “Conical Tower” in their greatest city.
The Shona people likely conducted substantial trade with a region of Africa known as the “[this language] coast.” This Bantu language has tons of speakers in Tanzania and Kenya.

answers: Notebooks for Anna Magdalena Bach [prompt on less specific answers, like Notebooks for J.S. Bach’s Wife]
Minuet in G major [or BWV Anh. 114]
parts: Name these collections of works which include aria “Bist du Bei Mir” and the first five of the composer’s “French” suites.

Perhaps the most famous work in the notebooks for Anna Magdalena is this G major piece for piano that is usually attributed to Christian Petzold. The melody of the piece starts like (read slowly) D-G-A-B-C D-G-G.
Bach included Les Bergeries by this French composer of Les Barricades Mystérieuses in the second notebook.

This author set the legend on a cruise ship, with the Fisher King as the wounded veteran Saul Henchman. He is also known for telling the story of Nick Jenkins in a twelve-book series including A Question of Upbringing.

This writer wrote about literary professor’s Persse McGarrigle’s attempt to woo Angelica Pabst, the daughter of the archly-named Arthur Kingfisher in Small World, featuring the professors Philip Swallow and Morris Zapp.

This author wrote about Wart and the backwards-living Merlin in The Sword and the Stone, before dealing more seriously with the Grail legend in The Ill-Made Knight, both parts of The Once and Future King.

answers: antiknock agents [or any variation of “preventing knocking”]
oxygen evolution [accept oxygen-evolving complex or OEC]
parts: Name this function also carried out by lead tetra-acetate, ferrocene, and iron pentacarbonyl. These gasoline additives prevent a phenomenon in which pockets of air/fuel mixtures explode independent of the combustion wave.

The center of MMT contains an atom of this element. A compound formed between potassium and an anion containing this element in its +7 oxidation state turns a deep purple color when dissolved in water.
Four manganese atoms are found in an complex that carries out this reaction in photosystem II. Water is split in this reaction, which turns the dye DCIP colorless.

Name this influential film critic who posited the “mummy complex” in “The Ontology of the Photographic Image,” an essay from his collection What is Cinema? Truffaut wrote for this man’s magazine, Cahiers du Cinema.

Under Bazin’s tutelage, Truffaut and the other Cahiers writers came up with this film theory concept, in which the director is recognized as the primary author of a film text. Its shares its name with the French word for “author.”

To demonstrate auteur theory, the editors of Cahiers du Cinema wrote an analysis of this director’s film Young Mr. Lincoln. This director of The Grapes of Wrath also made a film that begins and ends with shots of John Wayne’s character framed in a cabin’s doorway.
